channel.title: Bloomberg Markets
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Five Key Charts to Watch in Global Commodities This Week
item.description: Wildfires in Canada are threatening the country’s oil supply, while dry weather in the US is pushing initial ratings for corn and wheat to below average. Also down: American soybean and corn exports. The weather is taking its toll, even if artificial intelligence has improved the ability to predict it more accurately. And, US President Donald Trump’s disdain for electric vehicles doesn’t bode well for charging station installations.
item.dc:creator: Tope Alake, Robert Tuttle, Michael Hirtzer

media:content.media:description: Wildfire smoke above Highway 97 near Trutch, British Columbia, on May 30.

item.title: Trump Plans to Tap Biden’s Green Bank to Make Billions in Loans
item.description: The Trump administration plans to use a $400 billion green bank the president once sought to kill to finance billions of dollars in loans for nuclear reactors, geothermal power and critical minerals, according to details of the administration’s fiscal year 2026 budget request.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a news conference with Elon Musk, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., not pictured, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. The event gives an opportunity for the president and his largest campaign benefactor to dispel any notion of an acrimonious divorce.

item.title: Stocks Churn on Trade Risk as Dollar Near 2023 Low: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street investors parsing economic data, tariff and geopolitical developments sent stocks wavering. Bonds pared losses, while the dollar headed toward its lowest since 2023. Oil rallied.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

item.title: Mexico Judicial Election Sees 13% Turnout in Historic Vote
item.description: The future of Mexico’s judiciary was decided by a small minority of voters after an unprecedented election of federal judges, including all members of the nation’s top court.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Claudia Sheinbaum, Mexico’s president, casts a ballot at a polling station during the judicial elections in Mexico City, Mexico, on Sunday, June 1, 2025.

item.title: Jamie Dimon Talks Retirement Timeline
item.description: Jamie Dimon, the head of JPMorgan, says his retirement is “several years away." Sonali Basak and Matt Miller talk about Dimon's retirement timeline and why the big bank CEO is sticking around. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Boeing Upgraded to Buy at Bank of America as Trump Favors Planemaker for Trade Talks
item.description: The Trump administration has been including orders for Boeing Co. planes in trade discussions, and that’s helping to restore Bank of America Corp.’s confidence in the stock.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Griffin

media:content.media:description: Boeing Co. manufacturing facility in Renton, Washington.

item.title: The US Economy Has a Leak
item.description: Hello and welcome to the newsletter, a grab bag of daily content from the Odd Lots universe. Sometimes it's us, Joe Weisenthal and Tracy Alloway, bringing you our thoughts on the most recent developments in markets, finance and the economy. And sometimes it's contributions from our network of expert guests and sources. Whatever it is, we promise it will always be interesting.
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump speaks at the US Steel Corporation Irvin Works facility in West Mifflin, Pennsylvania, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. Trump said he would be increasing tariffs on steel to 50% from 25%, saying the move would help protect American steelworkers during a visit to a United States Steel Corp. plant on Friday. Photographer: Rebecca Droke/Bloomberg

item.title: Treasuries Fall as Tariff Concerns Cloud Outlook, ISM Weaker
item.description: Treasuries remained lower amid broad weakness in US assets on Monday, as worries over President Donald Trump’s tariff policy swirl at the start of a busy week for data on the health of the world’s largest economy.
item.dc:creator: James Hirai

item.title: Wall Street Sees Deeper Rout as Dollar Nears 2023 Low
item.description: Wall Street banks are reinforcing their calls that the dollar will weaken further, hit by interest-rate cuts, slowing economic growth and President Donald Trump’s trade and tax policies.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Carson, Aline Oyamada, Anya Andrianova

item.title: Alberta Wildfires Shut Down About 7% of Canada’s Oil Production
item.description: Wildfires in Canada’s energy heartland of Alberta have shut down almost 350,000 barrels of daily heavy crude production — about 7% of the country’s output — as a major blaze near the province’s eastern border menaces oil sands operations.
item.dc:creator: Robert Tuttle

media:content.media:description: Wildfire smoke above Highway 97 near Trutch, British Columbia, on May 30.

item.title: US Stocks Slip as Trade Friction, Weak Data Dent Sentiment
item.description: US equities edged lower Monday as reemerging tensions around global trade and a weak manufacturing report sapped investor confidence.
item.dc:creator: Esha Dey

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange.

item.title: The Ratings Underdog Making Waves in Private Credit
item.description: Egan-Jones is a small but significant player in the private credit market, grading over three thousand investments last year with a team of just 20 analysts. The firm's fast growth and optimistic ratings, however, are raising concerns about the risks in the private credit market, with some major investors excluding them from their lists of acceptable credit graders. Bloomberg Private Credit Reporter Silas Brown joined Wall Street Beat on Bloomberg Open Interest with the details. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Gold Surges With Rising Global Tensions Boosting Haven Demand
item.description: Gold surged on revived demand for safer assets as the US and China traded accusations, while a dramatic series of attacks clouded the prospects of peace between Russia and Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan, Yvonne Yue Li

item.title: Bloomberg Surveillance 6/2/2025
item.description: Jonathan Ferro, Lisa Abramowicz and Annmarie Hordern speak daily with leaders and decision makers from Wall Street to Washington and beyond. No other program better positions investors and executives for the trading day. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Diamond Wars: The Future of Lab Grown vs. Natural Diamonds
item.description: Lab Grown diamonds continue to put pressure on the $370 billion dollar global jewelry market. For the first time ever, more than half of engagement rings are made with lab grown diamonds. Despite the boom, De Beers says it will be closing its lab-grown diamond jewelry brand Lightbox. Ankur Daga, the Co-Founder and CEO of Angara, an online jeweler. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Some Retailers Can Get Away With Raising Prices, Widlitz Says
item.description: Stacey Widlitz, SW Retail Advisors president, says many consumers are still willing to pay higher prices, despite tariffs. She says many brands are getting away with raising prices if their products are in demand. She is on "Bloomberg Surveillance" talking about the impact of tariffs on retailers and says there could be fewer deals for customers in the electronic and footwear space. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: German Banks Pay Millions to Settle Claims by Insolvent Signa
item.description: Helaba and other German lenders have paid millions of euros in recent weeks to settle claims by the administrator of former real estate tycoon Rene Benko’s Signa Prime Selection AG.
item.dc:creator: Marton Eder

media:content.media:description: Hoardings with the Signa logo around a shopping center in Munich, Germany in March 2024.

item.title: Mali Court Postpones Ruling on Barrick Gold Mine to June 5
item.description: A Malian court has for the third time postponed a ruling on whether Barrick Gold Corp.’s Loulo-Gounkoto mine should be placed under state administration.
item.dc:creator: Katarina Hoije, Diakaridia Dembele

media:content.media:description: A dumper truck collects gold bearing rock ore from the digging floor of the Gounkoto open pit gold mine, part of the Loulo-Gounkoto mine complex, operated by Randgold Resources Ltd. in Gounkoto, Mali, on Friday, Nov. 1, 2013. Randgold Resources Ltd., a producer of the precious metal in Africa, said there are opportunities to acquire mines on the continent as the biggest companies in the industry scale back operations in the face of lower prices.

item.title: Eramet Drops as Gabon Aims to End Manganese Ore Exports
item.description: Eramet SA shares fell as much as 5.7% after Gabon decided to ban the export of manganese ore from 2029, jeopardizing the French miner’s biggest source of profit.
item.dc:creator: Francois De Beaupuy, William Clowes

item.title: Trump Wants to Sell 1 Million Barrel Reserve of Diesel Fuel
item.description: The Trump administration wants to put a 1 million barrel cache of diesel fuel on the market, saying the reserve meant to provide an emergency supply of home heating oil for the Northeast has never been used for its intended purpose.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter, Nathan Risser

item.title: Saylor’s Bitcoin Copycats Fall Behind as Speculative Pop Fizzles
item.description: Turns out, buying Bitcoin to boost your share price might not be the corporate panacea that it once seemed.
item.dc:creator: Monique Mulima

media:content.media:description: Michael Saylor during the Bitcoin 2025 conference in Las Vegas.

item.title: US Manufacturing Contracts for a Third Month
item.description: The Institute for Supply Management’s manufacturing index edged down 0.2 point last month to 48.5. The ISM’s import measure dropped 7.2 points, one of the largest monthly slides on record, to 39.9. Mike McKee reports on “Bloomberg Open Interest.” (Corrects to show third month of contraction)

item.title: Circle, Backers Seek $896 Million After Boosting IPO Size
item.description: Circle Internet Group Inc. and its shareholders have increased the size and price of the company’s initial public offering, suggesting strong investor demand for the stock.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes, Pablo Mayo Cerqueiro

item.title: Oil Advances as OPEC+ Supply Boost Vies With Geopolitical Risk
item.description: Oil surged after OPEC+ increased production less than some had feared and geopolitical concerns flared in Ukraine and Iran.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Mia Gindis

media:content.media:description: A flame burns off waste gas at Saudi Aramco's Ras Tanura oil refinery and terminal in Ras Tanura, Saudi Arabia, on Monday, Oct. 1, 2018. Saudi Aramco aims to become a global refiner and chemical maker, seeking to profit from parts of the oil industry where demand is growing the fastest while also underpinning the kingdom’s economic diversification.

item.title: US Aluminum and Steel Prices Surge as Trump Doubles Tariffs
item.description: Futures tracking aluminum and steel prices in the US surged after President Donald Trump said he will double tariffs on the metals this week.
item.dc:creator: Mark Burton

item.title: Bristol-Myers to Pay $11 Billion to License Cancer Drug
item.description: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. will pay BioNTech SE as much as $11.1 billion to license a next-generation cancer drug, as competition intensifies in an area of oncology that seeks to harness the immune system to attack tumors. Bloomberg's Damian Garde reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Can Starz Break into Hollywood's Big League?
item.description: Starz is fresh off its separation from Lionsgate and it's betting it can take on the likes of Netflix and HBO. The entertainment company added 530,000 streaming customers in the fourth quarter. STARZ President and CEO Jeffrey Hirsch joined Bloomberg Open Interest to talk about how he plans on transforming the company into a production powerhouse. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Quant Hedge Fund CFM Eyes Canada Expansion With Toronto Office
item.description: French quantitative hedge fund Capital Fund Management SA opened an office in Toronto to attract wealthy investors in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Chunzi Xu, Esteban Duarte

item.title: Matthei Gives Chile Vote Pledges a Reality Check on Fiscal Woes
item.description: Faced with an electoral campaign fought on two fronts — against the left and the hard right — Chile’s presidential front-runner Evelyn Matthei is trying to mark a difference not through sweeping promises, but by recognizing the cold, hard facts of a weak economy.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Presidential candidate for the Independent Democratic Union party, Evelyn Matthei, speaks during an event in Santiago, Chile, on May 19.

item.title: Revved-Up Polish Assets Dip as Election Erodes Pro-EU Tilt
item.description: Polish stocks and bonds — among the world’s stand-out performers of 2025 — dipped after a nationalist unexpectedly won the presidential election, dealing a blow to the government.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Krasuski, Tugce Ozsoy

media:content.media:description: Poll workers empty the ballot boxes at a primary school before they are counted during the second round of the presidential elections in Gdansk, on June 1, 2025. Photo Mateusz SLODKOWSKI / AFP/Getty Images
